Award.AwardTitle: The Geometry, Topology and Asymptotics of the Jones Polynomial
Award.AbstractNarration:
A knot is an embedded flexible circle in 3-space, with beginning and ends joined together, which allows to move in 3-space without crossing itself. Knots are fundamental 3-dimensional objects, rich enough to describe any possible 3-dimensional shape, and many 4-dimensional shapes, too. Knots appear microscopically on the atomic level (possibly used in topological quantum computing), in the molecular level (in the structure of DNA), and in the astronomical level (in the structure of black holes).

The Jones polynomial is a powerful knot invariant that keeps tightly locked key information about the geometry and topology of the knot complement. The purpose of the proposed research is to study the Geometry and Topology of the Jones polynomial that is revealed via asymptotic expansions, and especially its relation to hyperbolic geometry and representations of the fundamental group. The proposed research links together ideas from topology, geometry, algebra, number theory, analysis, quantum field theory and combinatorics. This requires the solution of hard analytic and combinatorial problems, and ultimately to a deeper geometric understanding of gauge theories in dimensions 3 and 4.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Knot theory is an old branch of low dimensional topology that has seen several phases and resurrections. Until the late 1970s, the classification methods used in knot theory employed the traditional tools of algebraic topology such as the fundamental group, homology, coverings, signatures of intersection forms and inspired the development of surgery theory in higher dimensions.

In the early 1980s W. Thurston proposed a completely different view of knots (and 3-manifolds) and formulated his famous Geometrization Conjecture, along with a proof for Haken manifolds, and particular for knot complements. This geometric approach to knot theory lead to a plethora of new invariants, such as the volume, the length spectrum and the invariant trace field of a knot. At the same time, a computer census of hyperbolic 3-manifolds was compiled, and allowed one to study global questions about the structure for the entire set of 3-manifolds.

About the same time, gauge theory type invariants in 4-dimensional topology (e.g. Donaldson, Mrowka and Kronheimer, Seiberg and Witten) were found and helped settle, among others, long open standing questions about smooth structures of 4-manifolds. More recently, Khovanov categorified the Jones polynomial, introducing link homology whose graded characteristic is the Jones polynomial, and Ozsvath and Szabo developed Heegaard-Floer homology, categorifying the Alexander polynomial. All these new invariants fit very well in the theory of TQFT.

The main question is to understand how Quantum Field Theory in dimension three detects the topology and geometry of the underlying space. The most famous connection between the Jones polynomial and hyperbolic geometry is the Volume Conjecture of Kashaev. The latter relates the exponential growth rate of evaluations of the colored Jones polynomial at complex roots of unity to the volume of the complement. In another direction, the Slope Conjecture of Garoufalidis relates the degree of the colored Jones polynomial to slopes of incompressible surfaces in the knot complement.

There are more recent Stability Conjectures that relate the coefficients of the colored Jones polynomial (when the color is sufficiently large) with q-series with integer coefficients, that in turn can be categorified via work of Witten and Dimofte-Gaiotto-Gukov, providing a missing link between the colored Jones polynomial and the celebrated Khovanov and Knot Floer Homology. The work done in the NSF grant DMS-0805078 brings together the various aspects ot Knot Theory and Quantum Topology.
